channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Half-court 'heaves' in the NBA will now count against the team
item.description: Starting this season, shot attempts taken more than 36 feet from the basket will be counted against the team, not the player. These NBA "freebies" have drawn all types of reactions.

item.title: Authorities have identified and arrested the man they say killed Charlie Kirk
item.description: President Trump announced that the man who authorities say shot and killed conservative activist Charlie Kirk has been arrested. Investigators identified him as 22-year-old Tyler Robinson.

item.title: Bolsonaro's meteoric rise, his stunning fall and what it means for Brazil's far right
item.description: Brazil's former President Jair Bolsonaro was sentenced to 27 years in prison for attempting a coup. Yet the former president remains one of the country's most consequential figures.

item.title: Why mothers in the U.S. are scaling back on their work lives
item.description: Workforce participation for moms in the U.S. has been dropping for most of this year, and the reasons are more complicated than return-to-office mandates. The team from "The Indicator" explains why.

item.title: 'The History of Sound' is a story of longing, set to music
item.description: Paul Mescal and Josh O'Connor play early 20th century music students in filmmaker Oliver Hermanus' poignant queer love story.

item.title: Spinal Tap returns with a rockin' sequel
item.description: Spinal Tap, the band from the beloved 1984 mockumentary about a fictional rock band, is back! Their new movie is called Spinal Tap II: The End Continues.

item.title: After the LA fires, some residents are moving old houses in from other neighborhoods
item.description: Those whose homes burned in the Los Angeles fires are making tough choices about whether to rebuild or move. A new project offers a third option: relocating homes to fire-affected lots.

item.title: Due to growing demand, a college in Denver now offers a degree in mariachi
item.description: Responding to "exploding" demand, a college in Denver now offers a Bachelor of Arts degree in Mariachi music. Students learn music and culture, but also business skills to build viable careers.

item.title: Your Pokemon cards could be valuable. Here's how to find out
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers talks with Justin Wilson about his Pokemon card collection, and he shares his tips for ascertaining a card or collection's value.

item.title: The future of HIV/AIDS after Trump's funding cuts
item.description: HIV has been in retreat around the world. But with cuts to foreign aid, it's less clear where the trend lines go from here. NPR's Ari Shapiro talks to author Emily Bass about the future of the virus.
